reviewText: John Cusack and Demi Moore are entertaining in this light comedy from the 80s. Bob Goldwait does some wacky stuff including dress up in a Godzilla suit and cause panic and destruction that will earn a few laughs. Moore plays a struggling singer as in "No Small Affair" that can't seem to get the money together in time to keep her house. Their zany group must find a boat and get it ship shape to enter the Regatta to win the trophy to trade for Moore's house so it won't be plowed under and made into Condos. This is of course by a underhanded rich family of snobs that have won the Regatta for years. If you are in the mood for some 80s style comedy this is a decent bet. Not quite the firepower of a "Ferris Bueller", but certainly worth a look. Good quality DVD with decent replayability. If you enjoyed this catch "Summer Rental" and "Better Off Dead".CA Luster
Title: N/A

reviewText: During the 80's there was a slew of teenage comedies. Savage Steve Holland is responsible - Better off Dead, How i got into College, and of course One Crazy Summer. John Cusack, bobcat Goldthwaite and Demi Moore! sign me up! Goofy fun, sight gags, its just totally 80's fun, i love it!

reviewText: What a classic movie.  How can you not dig such a funny movie?  I think you maybe need to be a true Gen X-er (I am...will be 35 later this year) to fully appreciate its humor.  It's not funny in the same way as say Weird Science, Sixteen Candles or Breakfast Club (other great movies by the way), but it still has its moments.  This is more that summer before you go to college or go find your place in the 'real world'.  This is less a "I can name every character in the movie because I know people like them" and more just a sit back and laugh movie that doesn't take itself too seriously.  How can it be taken seriously?  It has the immortal Bobcat in it.  It's even mostly family friendly.

reviewText: I loved this movie and several others that John Cusack did in the 80s and wanted to add it to my library.  While it was still cute and fun, it just seems more painful now with how hard they tried to slip the funny parts in.  I will probably keep it for my library, but not sure I would ever replace it if it were lost.  It's funny to look at the styles at the time the movie was made and it was good to see an early movie of Demi Moore's as well.
summary: A Classic that has lost it's flair in modern times

reviewText: We live in a time now where our expectations have exceeded our own imaginations. Furthermore, we live in a time where we're quick to put something down rather than overlook the minor details and enjoy the true story of the movie. The 1980s were a time when Film makers would take a chance, and while they weren't the best examples of fine cinema, they were a great way to pass time on a dreary indoor weekend. The first time I saw this film was on TV. I was a fan of Bobcat Goldwait's, so I had to see this movie. The movie was so much more, a hysterically memorable script by Savage Steve Holland, John Cusack's character, and a young un-hollywood spoiled Demi Moore.The story follows a guy who just can't find love, and the way it's told through his cartoon drawings is great. It follows him to Nantucket for the summer, where he and his family meet all kinds of locals, the crazy mechanics, as the seem to be in an odd competition/feud with the town's local Yuppies. The movie concludes with a boat race in true 80s movie fashion. The jokes are non stop, and the charm of this movie is what keeps me going back to it.

reviewText: As a huge fan of Savage Steve Holland's brilliant, mapcap debut Better Off Dead, I had high hopes when I cued up One Crazy Summer.  After all, it's the same director/writer, the same wacky worldview, the same absurdist comedy, even many returning cast members, including lead John Cusack, basically playing the same character. Gotta be a hoot, right?Sadly, no.  Not that One Crazy Summer doesn't have its moments.  There are still some inspired surreal gags and goofy, hammy performances by quasi-lunatic characters. But everything feels forced this time:  the timing and editing aren't as tight; there are fewer surprises;  the acting *too* broad (except Cusack, who sails through this asylum deadpan as always, barring those occasions when his imagination takes full animated flight -- altho' even these aren't as inspired as in the first film); and a too-big cast of supporting sidekicks diffuses the energy and plot objectives.  There is too much distracting Classic Rock  music shoehorned into the soundtrack  and I suspect that if you find Eighties comic Bobcat Goldthwait's schtick  as unfathomable and tiresome as I do, you will resent the amount of screen time spent on him.Not a bad movie by any means, and it has a decent message underneath and young Demi Moore is cute and appealing in a way she would seldom be again, so I'm going to goose it up a star more than I think it merits based purely on amused chuckles and a good heart.  In spite of the craziness of this summer, it seems far tamer and straighter than the meta-satire of Better Off Dead, and disappointed me while the earlier film never grows stale.
summary: Pallid follow-up to Better Off Dead falls flat
Title: N/A

reviewText: Holy cow, do I love this movie.  "Look!  The craziness!"This is one of those movies that played endlessly on HBO, and I remembered it quite fondly.  One day I threw it in the VCR and surprised myself by laughing almost nonstop through the whole thing.Sure, it seems a cookie-cutter comedy from the eighties, and it is, but look! the craziness!The brilliance of the movie is how it's situations keep slowly escalating into pure comic insanity.  Sure everybody remembers Bobcat Goldthwait rampaging in a Godzilla costume, but the seeds for the scene were presented about fifteen minutes ago and there was an uninterrupted continuity that took us from there to here.  This is pretty amazing for a "cookie-cutter" comedy.Really, it's this sense of mayhem that keeps bringing me back to the movie.  Mayhem.  That's what I want out of comedies, and this is one of its epitomes.  This and GREMLINS 2.But who cares about that?  This movie brings the funny.  What more could you ask for?  No thanks to all the cute and fuzzy bunnies in the world.
summary: Were you that little fat boy?
Title: N/A

reviewText: It must have been a close call whether they could make more money trying to sell this on DVD or getting the cast to pay them not to.  My advice: watch the movie, so you know how bad it is, then watch it again with the commentary by Curtis Armstrong, Bobcat Goldthwait (in his normal voice, thank God!) and Savage Steve Holland.  They know it's bad, and they love it.  You'll really enjoy it that second time, with what amounts to a running laugh track and better jokes than are in the movie.  It's a riot.
summary: You don't understand: she's gonna lose the house!

reviewText: I'm a huge fan of 80's movies, especially with John Cusack in them. "Better Off Dead" has been one of my favorites for most of my life. A friend recently suggested I see this film, so I bought it with the hopes it would be great. It was. I do not love it as much as the others, but it still has the quirky humor of that time which I absolutely love.If you do not like "Better Off Dead" I would not suggest this movie, because it plays on similar themes. The characters are all extremely quirky and at times the premise is unrealistic.

reviewText: This movie is not a major Academy award winner, but it is a winner in my book! If you are looking for the kind of laughter that brings tears to your eyes and just funny, this is the movie for you. With in movie jokes and puns that you have to watch carefully in order to catch them, this movie is sensitive and yet funny. Even now after not seeing this movie for several years, watching it again makes me laugh all the harder. Some actors in it are familiar and all are decent to say the least. If you order and watch it, you will not be disappointed.

reviewText: This movie was a mainstay during my childhood.  I watch it now and it's definitely not going to win an Oscar but it's still funny for sure, which is the point.  I think the cast was great and the writing was actually pretty good.  Funny, not too dumb all the time, a getting things done montage here and there, all the 80's movie elements!  Oh, and Bobcat Goldthwait...can't get more 80's than that(I know he's a brilliant dark comedy director now, but he'll always be known for his 80's persona).The movie isn't dirty, no nudity, low level of cursing so it wouldn't be a bad movie for a kid I don't think.As always with me, nostalgia rocks.  Enjoy!
summary: Campy 80's fare, but fun none the less
